docs.lead_paragraph: A group of more than 260 Broadway workers — cleaners, porters and bathroom attendants at about 30 theaters — has inched closer to a possible strike. A unanimous vote on Tuesday, in which more than 200 members of Local 32BJ of the Service Employees International Union participated, gave the union bargaining committee the authority to settle or strike. The workers are involved in negotiations with the Broadway League, which represents theater owners, and are seeking a pay raise of $1.50 an hour, a promise that their health insurance won’t be cut and additional pension benefits. The union’s contract expires on Dec. 31, though a spokesman said the last scheduled bargaining session would be on Thursday. Charlotte St. Martin, executive director of the Broadway League, said in a statement, “We are confident that we will reach an agreement in a reasonable period of time and are moving forward.”.

headline.main: Broadway Workers Tell Union to Settle or Strike

docs.lead_paragraph: The scuttling of a public option in the Senate health care bill has infuriated organized labor and left its leaders in a bind as to how to proceed. Top officials from several unions met with their executives Wednesday, and some planned to meet on Thursday to devise strategies now that the Senate has dropped plans for a public option, a government-run health insurance plan that would compete with private insurers. It is the central provision for which labor has been fighting.

docs.lead_paragraph: The new version of the Senate health care bill is ''a political disaster for Democrats -- a ticking time bomb for years to come.'' So warns Democracy for America, the organization founded by Howard Dean, former chairman of the Democratic National Committee, and led by his brother, Jim.
docs.abstract: Political group Democracy for America, founded by former Democratic National Committee chairman Howard Dean and run by his brother Jim, slams new version of Senate health care bill; since Senate Democrats dropped public option from their bill, Dean has urged Senate to scrap bill and start from scratch (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: When Massachusetts began offering virtually free treatments to help poor residents of the state stop smoking in 2006, proponents hoped the new Medicaid program would someday reap benefits. But state officials never expected it would happen so soon.

headline.main: A State's Lower Smoking Rate Draws Attention

docs.abstract: Preliminary study shows that smoking rate for poor residents in Massachusetts fell to 28.3 from 38.2 percent since 2006, when state began offering virtually free antismoking treatments through its public health plan; findings have grabbed national attention, with several United States senators and antismoking advocates using data to push for similar new Medicaid coverage for tobacco addiction in national health care legislation; photos; chart (M)
